title: Paris-Roubaix tech gallery 2025: 1x chainrings, Cervélo Soloist and Gravaa tyre pressure adjuster
content:
Cyclist
Paris-Roubaix tech gallery 2025: 1x chainrings, Cervélo Soloist and Gravaa tyre pressure adjuster

Historically Paris-Roubaix can be a tough day out for team sponsors. Modifications galore, broken bikes, crumpled wheels, punctures ending races. Things have gotten a bit more sensible in recent years though, with the peloton embracing wider and tubeless tyres, the details tend to be more intricate.

Still, (most of) the bikes on display in both the men’s and women’s races have been adapted for the harsh cobbles of northern France, so we sent photographer Xavier Pereyron behind the scenes to see what he could find.

Q36.5 took advantage of their SRAM partnership to go 1x, with a Wolf Tooth chain catcher to keep things in place. Jannik Steimle was one of many riders on a 54T chainring.

Unibet Tietema Rockets got to get their striking colours in a Monument for the first time, though Lukáš Kubiš’s Slovakian national champs colours make things a bit more sensible. He was running the most popular option of 32mm tyres and 54/40T up front.

British rider Max Walker had a spell in the early breakaway, he had 32mm Vittoria Corsa Pros.

Good sticker work. With riders wanting more bar tape on the tops, the sponsors get covered up, but thankfully EF had a solution.

Pro bike: Tadej Pogačar’s Tour of Flanders Colnago V4Rs

Lotto had young Brit Josh Giddings on 30mm tyres. The team are also using lightweight Galfer rotors.

Very official nutrition plan.

This Jayco-AlUla chainring looks like it would make a great takeaway container lid. With Shimano not producing a 1x road groupset, riders had to turn to custom chainrings to get that benefit with the rest of their Dura-Ace setup.

As he did in the Classics in 2024, Wout van Aert went for the Cervélo Soloist over the aero S5. Considering his form fourth was a good result, so it was probably a good move. He was on a 1x 54T chainring with 32mm tyres.

He had a nice picture of his Masked Singer outfit on his stem.

Most noteworthy though is the team’s use of the Gravaa adjustable tyre pressure system.

The added weight in the hubs won’t have caused much of an issue with so little elevation.

The Ridley Noah Fast looks crazy at the best of times, add in a set of aero gravel wheels and some huge 35mm tyres and it’s pure Roubaix delight.

Lidl-Trek had all sorts going on including 1x chainrings all round, SRAM Red AXS XPLR gravel rear derailleur and rubber bands to make the aero bottles cages more secure.

Who needs rubber bands? Not Tadej Pogačar.

He did need a long list of notes though. And more bar tape than usual.

There looks to have been a bit of damage covered up on the seat stays and dropouts.

He’s easy to spot from every angle.

More 54T 1x and 32mm tyres for Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe, who teased potential Specialized Roubaix usage but the Tarmac still reigns supreme even here.

Stefan Küng was another with 35mm tyres, which he had fitted to enormous 62mm deep Miche wheels.

Cofidis had pretty sensible setups, just the increase to 32mm tyres.

After they’ve been out for the whole Classics season, Paris-Roubaix seems like the only race where the Zipp tyre pressure sensor wheels would be useful. Although if you puncture here you know about it.

Biniam Girmay had a good race with his fresh Newmen full carbon wheels and Hutchinson tyres. His Intermarché team were also making use of bar tape that attaches to matching gloves.

That’s a nice sticker to have.

XDS-Astana continued their strong start to the year with another pretty normal setup.

This is where BMC regrets making the Teammachine R 01’s tyre clearance to small. There’s so much room at the sides but Tudor can barely fit bigger tyres in.

They went for the gravel wheels too.

There some differing opinions in the Decathlon-AG2R camp, some went for the RCR Pro (with custom carbon chainrings)…

… others went for the new RCR-F with SwissSide’s all-road wheels and big tyres.

Filippo Ganna is a very big man, but unlike his teammates – like Josh Tarling who probably had the biggest chainring in the peloton with a 62T – the Italian had a sensible 54T.

Hugo Hofstetter went big on the aero, with 58mm Black Inc rims. Israel-Premier Tech were using FSA single chainrings, and you can even see the tape covering where the front derailleur normally goes.

Picnic-PostNL’s Julius van den Berg went for 56-44T chainrings.

Bahrain Victorious were all on 35mm all-season Continental Grand Prix 5000 tyres.

Onto the women’s now and Winspace-Orange Seal got some TV time early on with Aurela Nerlo. This bike belongs to Irish champ Fiona Mangan, who matched the men’s peloton with her 54T outer chainring and 32mm Hutchinson tyres.

Lotto’s women’s team had more normal disc rotors than the men’s team.

VolkerWessels’ colour scheme makes for some very pretty bikes, although Maud Rijnbeek’s small Tarmac makes that head tube look very exaggerated.

If any specific product is winning from the modifications it’s DT Swiss’s GRC wheels.

Coop-Repsol are keeping the Hunt wheels big race representation going.

But you’d have hoped in 2025 SRAM could’ve sent them Red AXS groupsets.

Some one-upping going on with Cofidis, Martina Alzini went for 34mm tyres.

It was a good debut for Chloé Dygert, with her new fancy-coloured Aeroad.

She was running a 52T single chainring.

Whose is this? There might be a slightly giveaway.

It’s Lotte Kopecky of course. She turns her bars down slightly rather than having a negative stem angle.

Kopecky doesn’t mess around with her notes. Cobbles only.

Lorena Wiebes had a small chainring compared to most at 50T, and her 32mm Specialized Mondo tyres look much bigger than they are.

This angle of SD Worx’s collection gives a good impression of how individual the setups are, with most riders having different stems and all having different saddles.

Conti team DD Group were riding very slick BMCs with custom chainrings, but again, come on Shimano it’s Paris-Roubaix get the Dura-Ace out.

Visma’s women’s team were also using the Gravaa systems, but it’s safe to say their choices paid off a bit more than the men.

Including Marianne Vos sticking to her trusty S5.

Vittoria Guazzini was flying the flag for tan wall Continentals.

Maybe Pogačar should’ve used notes like this with indicators of the cobble sectors with turns.

Nice to see Mavic still getting the runout in the big races courtesy of St Michel-Preference Home-Auber 93.

This might be the last Bianchi at Roubaix for a while given Arkéa’s struggles and the impending relegations at the end of the season.

UAE Team ADQ’s Tereza Neumanova was on GoPro duty. That’s a good test for the stabilisation features.

She also made sure to cover up those carbon tops.

Cat Ferguson was running the tyre pressure sensor wheels too, but unfortunately her race ended prematurely.

Finally there was no funny business for Roubaix warrior Alison Jackson, just the wider tyres.

author: Will Strickson | Website Editor
